column3: The US economy would be substantially stronger today if the state and local ‘stay-at-home’ orders had been more uniform and lasted longer in the first half of the year.
column4: Confidence in this topic (10 being the highest).
column5: Please explain your response in 140 characters or less.
column6: The economy will receive a substantial boost as soon as K-12 schools can be safely opened in person nationwide.
column7: Confidence in this topic (10 being the highest).
column8: Please explain your response in 140 characters or less.

column5: With better lockdown policies, there would have been tens of thousands of fewer deaths, but probably not much better GDP outcomes.
column8: The key word is SAFELY. That means COVID is under control. If schools open without that, second wave would be much worse and GDP would fall.

column5: Korea is the best case scenario. Germany had its act together. The U.S. response was chaotic, and this has slowed the eventual rebound
column8: Boost will come *years later* when students reach the labor market with more skills. Status quo is a disaster for human capital formation!

column5: Less people would have died--that is what we know for sure.
column8: I don't know why opening of schools would have a large causal effect, but may be it is a signal the economy can coordinate on.

column5: more uniform: yes; longer: less clear vs, say, strict mandating of masks and social distancing.
The intervention should have been earlier, more targeted, and more thoughtful (complemented with more efficient testing and tracing).
The economy would be stronger if the stay at home time was used productively to rapidly ramp up testing and other virus responses.
column8: Opening schools likely has a direct effect but also the question implies an environment in which the virus is under more control.

column5: There are many many puzzling features of the dynamics of the pandemic, both here and around the world. So hard to know.
column8: Especially women

column5: Yes, although we have since learned that very extensive use of masks, without a stay-at-home order, would have worked and been less costly.
column8: Parents could then resume more productive work. Also, this likely generates short-run and long-run benefits for children.
Likely to depend on time frame.  If schools accelerate the virus spread a short-term boost might be more than offset later

column5: Widespread availability of testing enabling targeted stay-at-home orders together with contact tracing would have made for stronger economy
column8: "as soon as" is different from "because". When schools are safe to open, other activities will also be safe, making for a substantial boost.
If causality is pandemic over, economy expands and schools open, it is the pandemic over, not the schools opening, that is the cause.

column5: We needed to slow the spread of the virus (still do). Consistency would help as would but it isn't just about shelter-in-place
column8: You can't go to work if your kid has nowhere to go

column5: Unclear benefits of stay at home without without rigorous tracing, contact tracing, quarantining etc
column8: I agree bc the question implies that we have a vaccine or herd immunity

column5: Research shows that almost all precautionary behavior would have occurred absent government orders
column8: Ability to have universal K-12 in-person schooling would be a sign of advanced progress in all respects against the virus.

column5: More targeted lockdowns that encouraged more economic activity would have done better.
Natural caution was very important, hard to know if just stay at home would have been enough to control the virus spread.
column8: presumably other activities would also become safe then too

column5: Voluntary social distancing has been more uniform than lockdown policies.
column8: Partly causal, but more as an indicator.

column5: Yes if uno]iform pol
column8: ‘Safely’ is big part of plan.

column5: There are great returns to mitigating a potentially exponential process early, and doing so uniformly (to avoid weakest-link vulnerabilies.
column8: Education has long-run returns as well as well as great short-run returns in facilitating labor force participation of others.

column5: Unknowable.  More businesses would have failed early on. Lots would depend on policies after the stay-at-home orders expired.
column8: Emphasis on "safely".

column5: Stronger lockdowns in some European countries have not prevented the need for second lockdowns.
But only if followed up by masks, testing & quarantine, etc upon reopening; more severe shutdowns alone wouldn't keep the virus suppressed.
column8: The predicate for safe K-12 reopening is suppression of the virus and a strategy to keep it so; that plus freeing parents' time is key.

column5: Yeah, probably but so many variables at play that it is hard to be sure about anything. Laws are not enforced.
column8: Will certainly help families with small children. Female labor force participation is way down. Same as it ever was.

column5: I would be very confident if the longer & more uniform closings were accompanied by more testing and better tracing.
